article.name: Copy a .bat File When Installing the Phish Alert Button (PAB) Through Group Policy
article.title: Copy a .bat File When Installing the Phish Alert Button (PAB) Through Group Policy
article.body:
To install the Phish Alert Button (PAB) through Group Policy (GPO), you will need to copy the .bat file to the GPO object folder located in the SYSVOL folder. There are two ways to do this: copy the .bat file to the Network Share folder of the local SYSVOL folder, or copy the .bat file to the local SYSVOL folder directly.

Access the SYSVOL Folder Through Share Permissions

To access the SYSVOL folder through share permissions, follow the steps below:

  1. Open the Share and Storage Management console.
  2. Double-click the SYSVOL folder to open the SYSVOL Properties pop-up window.

  1. In the SYSVOL Properties pop-up window, click the Permissions tab.
  2. Under the Permissions tab, click the NTFS Permissions button to open the Permissions for sysvol pop-up window.

  1. In the Permissions for sysvol pop-up window, grant yourself Modify privileges by selecting the check box under the Allow column. Click the OK button.

Note:If applicable, grant yourself Change privileges under Share Permissions.
  1. You should now be able to copy the .bat file to the local startup script location. The startup script location will open when you click the Show Files... button in the Startup Properties window.

Access the SYSVOL Folder Through the Local Hard Drive

To access the SYSVOL folder through the local hard drive, follow the steps below:

  1. Navigate to C:\Windows\SYSVOL\sysvol on your workstation. 

  1. Then, continue the path to the startup script folder location.
  2. In the startup script folder location, directly copy the .bat file.

The image displays the **SYSVOL Properties** dialog box, specifically showing the content of the active **Permissions** tab.

**UI Context and Text:**

*   **Dialog Title:** SYSVOL Properties
*   **Active Tab:** Permissions (The Sharing tab is also visible but inactive).
*   **Explanatory Text:** The primary text defines the relationship between Share permissions and NTFS permissions, stating: "For network access... the more restrictive of the share and NTFS permissions determine the level of access granted to users and groups."
*   **Share Permissions Section:** Provides instructions for setting network access permissions and includes the operational button: **Share Permissions**.
*   **NTFS Permissions Section:** Provides instructions for setting local access permissions and includes the operational button: **NTFS Permissions**.
*   **Instructional Overlay:** A large orange arrow is overlaid on the dialog, originating near the "Permissions" tab and pointing directly at the **NTFS Permissions** button, highlighting this element.
*   **Reference Link:** A footer link is present for documentation: **Managing Permissions for Shared Folders**.
*   **Control Buttons:** The footer contains standard controls: **OK**, **Cancel**, and a grayed-out (disabled) **Apply** button.

images.alt:
The image displays two nested Windows property dialog boxes related to security permissions for a folder named **SYSVOL**.

**Foreground Dialog: "Permissions for sysvol"**
This dialog is active and shows the **Security** tab.

1.  **Group or user names:** The list displays five security principals. **Authenticated Users** is selected and highlighted.
2.  **Permissions for Authenticated Users:** This section lists the NTFS permissions granted to the selected group.
    *   The permissions listed are **Full Control**, **Modify**, **Read & Execute**, **List Folder Contents**, and **Read**.
    *   An orange instructional arrow points directly at the **Modify** permission row.
    *   Checkboxes under the **Allow** and **Deny** columns are visible for each permission, none of which are currently checked.
3.  **Action Buttons:** Standard configuration buttons are present, including **Add...**, **Remove**, **Advanced**, **OK**, **Cancel**, and **Apply**.

**Background Dialog: "SYSVOL Properties"**
This dialog, which launched the foreground window, is partially visible.

1.  **Tabs:** The **Permissions** tab is selected, adjacent to the **Sharing** tab.
2.  **Context:** The window explains the difference between Share and NTFS permissions.
3.  **Buttons:** Two key buttons are visible: **Share Permissions** and **NTFS Permissions**.

The image displays the **Startup Properties** configuration window, typically found within a Microsoft Windows Group Policy Object (GPO) editor.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Window Title:** The dialog box is titled "**Startup Properties**."
2.  **Tab Controls:** Two tabs are present: "**Scripts**" and "**PowerShell Scripts**." The **Scripts** tab appears to be the currently active selection.
3.  **Heading:** The content area is labeled "**Startup Scripts for Local Computer**."
4.  **Script List:** An empty list box is displayed, featuring columns for "**Name**" and "**Parameters**" to list configured scripts.
5.  **Action Buttons:** A set of vertically stacked buttons are present:
    *   **Up** and **Down** (disabled/greyed out).
    *   **Add...** (enabled).
    *   **Edit...** and **Remove** (disabled/greyed out).
6.  **Instructional Text:** Below the script list, the text states: "To view the script files stored in this Group Policy Object, press the button below."
7.  **Key Action Button:** The button labeled "**Show Files...**" is active, highlighted by an orange oval and arrow, indicating it is the required action to view the script repository location.
8.  **Standard Dialog Controls (Bottom):** The window concludes with three standard buttons: **OK**, **Cancel**, and **Apply** (currently disabled/greyed out).
